Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.
Runs posting on in Bolingbroke's proud joy,
Run with these false and most contrarious quests
Run to my study. By and by! God's will,
Run reeking o'er the lives of men, as if
Run not before mine honour, nor my lusts
Rumour it abroad
Rue, even for ruth, here shortly shall be seen,
Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow
Royally!
Royal commanders, be in readiness:
Rouse up thy youthful blood, be valiant and live.
Roundly replied.
Rough cradle for such little pretty ones!
Rosaline; Livia; Signior Valentio and his cousin
Romeo.
Romeo, will you come to your father's? we'll
Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet;
Romeo, the hate I bear thee can afford
Romeo, that she were, O, that she were
Romeo, good night: I'll to my truckle-bed;
Romeo, come forth; come forth, thou fearful man:
Romeo, bon jour! there's a French salutation
Romeo, away, be gone!
Romeo, I come! this do I drink to thee.
Romeo's a dishclout to him: an eagle, madam,
Romeo! my cousin Romeo!
Romeo! humours! madman! passion! lover!
Romeo! O, pale! Who else? what, Paris too?
Romeo!
Romeo!
Romeo will answer it.
Romeo that spoke him fair, bade him bethink
Romeo that kill'd him, he is banished.
Romeo slew him, he slew Mercutio;
Romeo slew Tybalt, Romeo must not live.
Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.
Romeo is coming.
Romeo is banish'd; and all the world to nothing,
Romeo can,
Rome, especially his mother, may prevail with him.
Rome and her rats are at the point of battle;
Roman:
Roman:
Roman:
Roman:
Roman:
Roman:
Roman:
Roman:
Roman:
Roman:
Rode he on Barbary? Tell me, gentle friend,
Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand;
Rivers and Dorset, you were standers by,
Rise up, good aunt.
Rights by rights falter, strengths by strengths do fail.
Right.
Right.
Right, you say true: as Hereford's love, so his;
Right, I mean you.
Right,
Right well, dear madam. By your patience,
Right true it is, your son Lucentio here
Right son to the right Vincentio;
Right noble is thy merit, well I wot.
Right gracious lord, I cannot brook delay:
Right glad I am he was not at this fray.
Rideth a puissant navy; to the shore
Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.
Richmond, in Yorkshire, sent out a boat
Richmond! When last I was at Exeter,
Richmond is on the seas.
Richly in both, if justice had her right.
Richard, enough; I will be king, or die.
Richard, be Duke of Gloucester. Now to London,
Richard, I will create thee Duke of Gloucester,
Richard, I bear thy name; I'll venge thy death,
Richard!
Richard yet lives, hell's black intelligencer,
Richard the second here was hack'd to death;
Richard of York! how fares our loving brother?
Richard of Bordeaux, by me hither brought.
Richard not far from hence hath hid his head.
Richard loves Richard; that is, I am I.
Richard hath best deserved of all my sons.
Richard except, those whom we fight against
Richard cried 'Charge! and give no foot of ground!'
Richard and Hastings: let them go; here is The duke.
Rich men look sad and ruffians dance and leap,
Rich garments, linens, stuffs and necessaries,
Reward to him that brings the traitor in?
Reward did threaten and encourage him,
Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.
Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse:
Revolt our subjects? that we cannot mend;
Revoke that doom of mercy, for 'tis Clifford;
Revive, look up, or I will die with thee!
Revenged may she be on that hateful duke,
Reveal yourself to him.
Return, good Catesby, to thy lord again;
Return'd my letter back. Then all alone
Return with welcome home from banishment.
Return unto thy lord; commend me to him:
Return to the tribunes.
Return me, as Cominius is return'd,
Return him here again. Go with him, provost.
Return again, and take an oath with thee.
Retorts it: Romeo he cries aloud,
Retire to win our purpose.
Retain that dear perfection which he owes
Resume that spirit, when you were wont to say,
Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry's corse.
Rest you merry!
Rest thy unrest on England's lawful earth,
Respecting her that's gone. Besides, the gods
Respect to your great place! and let the devil
Resolved. resolved.
Resolved for flight. Now were I happy, if
Resolve thee, Richard; claim the English crown.
Resolve my doubt. You twain, of all the rest,
Resign'd the crown to Henry the Fourth,
Resign thy chair, and where I stand kneel thou,
Resides not in that man that does not think,--
Rescued the Black Prince, that young Mars of men,
Rescue, my Lord of Norfolk, rescue, rescue!
Rescue, fair lord, or else the day is lost!
Rescue thy mistress, if thou be a man.
Requite your love!
Requires nor child nor woman's face to see.
Reproach and dissolution hangeth over him.
Reprieve thee from thy fate, it should proceed:
Reports, the Volsces with two several powers
Report of fashions in proud Italy,
Repented o'er his doom.
Repent you, fair one, of the sin you carry?
Repent what you have spoke.
Repent in their election.
Repeal him with the welcome of his mother;
Repair'd with double riches of content.
Repair to the senate-house.
Repair to the Capitol.
Renowned queen, with patience calm the storm,
Renowned prince, how shall poor Henry live,
Renowned for their deeds as far from home,
Renown'd in Padua for her scolding tongue.
Remove you hence: I knew you at the first
Remnants of packthread and old cakes of roses,
Remit thy other forfeits. Take him to prison;
Remembering how I love thy company.
Remember, as thou read'st, thy promise pass'd:
Remember since you owed no more to time
Remember our reward, when the deed is done.
Remember Margaret was a prophetess.'
Remember I have done thee worthy service;
Remaining in the coffer of her friends,
Remain a pinch'd thing; yea, a very trick
Relish a truth like us, inform yourselves
Relenting fool, and shallow, changing woman!
Relent, and save your souls.
Relent! 'tis cowardly and womanish.
Release my brother; and, after much debatement,
Relate your wrongs; in what? by whom? be brief.
Reignier, her father, to the king of France
Regard me as I do not flatter, and
Refusing her grand hests, she did confine thee,
Refused most princely gifts, am bound to beg
Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffer'd love.
Redeem from broking pawn the blemish'd crown,
Red as 'twould burn Rome; and his injury
Recover breath; tell us how near is danger,
Recoil upon me: in himself too mighty,
Receive thy lance; and God defend the right!
Receive in either by this dear encounter.
Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace,
Rebell'd against the belly, thus accused it:
Reason; because they then less need one another.
Real necessities, and give way the while
Ready, with every nod, to tumble down
Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road.
Ready to go, but never to return.
Ready to fight; therefore be resolute.
Ready to catch each other by the throat,
Read the indictment.
Read o'er this paper while the glass doth come.
Read o'er the volume of young Paris' face,
Read it.
Read it not, noble lords;
Re-quicken'd what in flesh was fatigate,
Re-purchased with the blood of enemies.
Razed out my imprese, leaving me no sign,
Rather to show a noble grace to both parts
Rather than they shall pound us up: our gates,
Rather than have that savage duke thine heir
Rather than envy you.
Rather than Paris. These are news indeed!
Rather rejoicing to see another merry, than merry at
Rather our state's defective for requital
Ratcliff, thyself, or Catesby; where is he?
Ratcliff, my lord; 'tis I. The early village-cock
Ratcliff, about the mid of night come to my tent
Ratcliff!
Ransoming him, or pitying, threatening the other;
Ran on the green-sward: nothing she does or seems
Raised only, that the weaker sort may wish
Raise up the Montagues: some others search:
Rain'd from the wounds of slaughter'd Englishmen:
Rail on the Lord's enointed: strike, I say!
Rage must be withstood:
Rage like an angry boar chafed with sweat?

Quick is mine ear to hear of good towards him.

Puts my apparel and my countenance on,
Put we our quarrel to the will of heaven;
Put up your swords; you know not what you do.
Put up your swords.
Put this in any liquid thing you will,
Put them not to't:
Put them in secret holds, both Barnardine and Claudio:
Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.
Put on thee by my lord, thou ne'er shalt see
Put on the gown, stand naked and entreat them,
Put not your worthy rage into your tongue;
Put not another sin upon my head,
Put in their hands thy bruising irons of wrath,
Put in her tender heart the aspiring flame
Put him to choler straight: he hath been used
Put finger in the eye, an she knew why.
Pursuivant:
Pursuivant:
Pursuivant:
Pursued my humour not pursuing his,
Pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence:
Purge all infection from our air whilst you
Purchase the sight again of dear Sicilia
Provost:
Provost:
Provost:

Provost:
Provost, my brother Angelo will not be altered;
Provost, how came it Claudio was beheaded
Provost, a word with you.
Provost, a word with you!
Provokes this deluge most unnatural.
Provoked by him, you cannot--the great danger
Provoke us hither now to slaughter thee.
Provided that, when he's removed, your highness
Provided that my banishment repeal'd
Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests;
Prove violence; in the which three great ones suffer,
Prove me, my gracious sovereign.
Prove it, Henry, and thou shalt be king.
Prove it before these varlets here, thou honourable
Prove as successful to the queen,--O be't so!--
Prove armed soldiers, ere her native king
Proud setter up and puller down of kings!
Proud majesty a subject, state a peasant.
Proud can I never be of what I hate;
Prosperity's the very bond of love,
Prosperity be thy page!
Prosper you, sweet sir!
Proportionable to the enemy
Proportion'd as one's thought would wish a man;
Properly ours.
Proof?
Pronounce thee a gross lout, a mindless slave,
Pronounce a sentence on your brother's life:
Promotion follows. If I could find example
Profess'd to him, why, his revenges must
Profess'd the contrary.
Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,--
Profaned, dishonour'd, and the third usurp'd.
Produce the prisoner.
Prodigious, and untimely brought to light,
Prodigious birth of love it is to me,
Procure your sureties for your days of answer.
Procure me music ready when he wakes,
Proclaims him king, and many fly to him:
Proclaimed a strumpet: with immodest hatred
Proclaim you are no less! Can you so stead me
Proclaim it, provost, round about the city.
Proclaim an enshield beauty ten times louder
Proclaim a pardon to the soldiers fled
Proceeded to you; therefore take your honours.
Proceed:
Proceed.
Proceed thus rashly to the villain's death,
Proceed in practise with my younger daughter;
Proceed in justice, which shall have due course,
Privy to none of this. How will this grieve you,
Prithee, son, do; for we must be gentle, now we are
Prithee, peace.
Prithee, peace.
Prithee, no more; cease; thou know'st
Prithee, no more: thou dost talk nothing to me.
Prithee, let him.
Prithee, fellow, remember my name is Menenius,
Prithee, be my present partner in this business, and
Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside and see the end of
Prithee now, say you will, and go about it.
Prithee now,
Prithee bring him in; and let him approach singing.
Princes have but their tides for their glories,
Princes and noble lords,
Priest:
Prick'd from the lazy finger of a maid;
Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down.
Preys on the issue of his mother's body,
Prevent it, resist it, let it not be so,
Prevail not, go and see: if you can bring
Pretty! What say you, Hugh Rebeck?
Pretty too! What say you, James Soundpost?
Presuming on an ague's privilege,
Press me not, beseech you, so.
Preserver of my father, now of me,
Presented to my knife his throat: I took him;
Present our services to a fine new prince
Preposterous ass, that never read so far
Prepare you, lords, for Edward is at hand.
Prepare thy brow to frown: know'st
Prepare thy battle early in the morning,
Prepare her, wife, against this wedding-day.
Prepare her ears to hear a wooer's tale
Preoccupied with what you rather must do
Prefix'd for's parting: yet, good deed, Leontes,
Prefix'd by Angelo: see this be done,
Prefer them hither; for to cunning men
Pray, sir, in what?
Pray, sir, by your good favour,--for surely, sir, a
Pray, let us go.
Pray, let us go.
Pray, good shepherd, what fair swain is this
Pray, get you out.
Pray, be counsell'd:
Pray, be content:
Pray, Master Barnardine, awake till you are
Pray you, who does the wolf love?
Pray you, take note of it: and when you have
Pray you, put up your dagger, and put out your wit.
Pray you, poor gentleman, take up some other
Pray you, my lord, give me leave to question; you
Pray you, let's to him.
Pray you, let's hear.
Pray you, go to him.
Pray you, go fit you to the custom and
Pray you, do.
Pray you, be gone:
Pray you, be gone.
Pray you, a word.
Pray you then,
Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your
Pray you now, buy it.
Pray so; and, for the ordering your affairs,
Pray now, your news?
Pray now, sit down.
Pray now, no more: my mother,
Pray now, no more.
Pray now, buy some: I love a ballad in print o'
Pray heartily he be at palace.
Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.
Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!
Pray God we may make haste, and come too late!
Pray God the plants thou graft'st may never grow.
Praised!
Praise her but for this her without-door form,
Pour all your tears! I am your sorrow's nurse,
Pots, and, I think, forty more; all great doers in

Post you to London, and you will find it so;
Post thou to Salisbury
Poor thing, condemn'd to loss!
Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.
Poor sacrifices of our enmity!
Poor queen! so that thy state might be no worse,
Poor queen! how love to me and to her son
Poor queen and son, your labour is but lost;
Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune!
Poor living corse, closed in a dead man's tomb!
Poor key-cold figure of a holy king!
Poor heart, adieu! I pity thy complaining.
Poor harmless lambs abide their enmity.
Poor breathing orators of miseries!
Poor Clifford! how I scorn his worthless threats!
Poor Clarence did forsake his father, Warwick;
Pompey: you will turn good husband now, Pompey; you
Pompey.
Polixenes for Leontes: O thou thing!
Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end:
Poison hath residence and medicine power:
Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel,
Pluck'd from my arms perforce and given away
Pluck'd four away.
Pluck up thy spirits; look cheerfully upon me.
Plough Rome and harrow Italy: I'll never
Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous,
Pleased you to do't at peril of your soul,
Please your highness, posts
Please you, sir,
Please you to interpose, fair madam: kneel
Please you to do't,
Please you to accept it, that the queen is spotless
Please you dismiss me either with 'ay' or 'no.'
Please ye we may contrive this afternoon,
Please it your majesty to give me leave,
Please but your honour hear me.
Pleads he in earnest? look upon his face;
Plead what I will be, not what I have been;
Plays such fantastic tricks before high heaven
Plays fondly with her tears and smiles in meeting,
Players:
Play'd for a pair of stainless maidenhoods:
Play too, but so disgraced a part, whose issue
Play the men.
Play the maid's part, still answer nay, and take it.
Plaster you o'er, that you may be abhorr'd
Plantagenet.
Plantagenet, of thee and these thy sons,
Plantagenet, for all the claim thou lay'st,
Plantagenet! I come, Plantagenet!
Plantagenet shall speak first: hear him, lords;
Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet.
Plainly conceive, I love you.
Plainly as heaven sees earth and earth sees heaven,
Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.
Places remote enough are in Bohemia,
Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes
Pity may move thee 'pardon' to rehearse.
Pitiful sight! here lies the county slain,
Piteous predicament! Even so lies she,
Pitchers have ears.
Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants:
Pisa renowned for grave citizens.
Pisa renown'd for grave citizens
Pins and poking-sticks of steel,
Pink for flower.
Piercing our Romans: then, valiant Titus, take
Pierced to the soul with slander's venom'd spear,
Pewter and brass and all things that belong
Petruchio, stand by a while.
Petruchio, since we are stepp'd thus far in,
Petruchio, shall I then come roundly to thee
Petruchio, patience; I am Grumio's pledge:
Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.
Petruchio, I shall be your ben venuto.
Petruchio is my name; Antonio's son,
Petitioners for blood thou ne'er put'st back.
Peter, take my fan, and go before and apace.
Peter, stay at the gate.
Peter, didst ever see the like?
Peter!
Peter!
Peruse this writing here, and thou shalt know
Persuades when speaking fails.
Persuades me it is otherwise: howe'er it be,
Persuades me I was better when a king;
Persuade this rude wretch willingly to die.
Persuade the queen to send the Duke of York
Persuade him that he hath been lunatic;
Perpetual durance?
Permitted by our dastard nobles, who
Perjury, perjury, in the high'st degree
Perhaps, him and her, sir: what have you to do?
Perhaps you mark'd not what's the pith of all.
Perhaps you have learned it without book: but, I
Perhaps thy childishness will move him more
Perhaps thou wilt object my holy oath:
Perhaps they had ere this, but that they stay
Perfume for a lady's chamber;
Perform'd to point the tempest that I bade thee?
Perform'd in this wide gap of time since first
Perchance she cannot meet him: that's not so.
Perchance shall dry your pities: but I have
Perchance are to this business purblind? say.
Pembroke and Stafford, you in our behalf
Peering in April's front. This your sheep-shearing
Peer'd forth the golden window of the east,
Pedascule, I'll watch you better yet.

Peace, you mumbling fool!
Peace, wilful boy, or I will charm your tongue.
Peace, thou! and give King Henry leave to speak.
Peace, sirrah!
Peace, peace; be not so loud.
Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!
Peace, peace!
Peace, master marquess, you are malapert:
Peace, impudent and shameless Warwick, peace,
Peace, ho, for shame! confusion's cure lives not
Peace, ho! no outrage: peace!
Peace, foolish woman.
Peace, children, peace! the king doth love you well:
Peace, both, and hear me speak.
Peace, Tranio!
Peace, I have done. God mark thee to his grace!
Peace, Grumio! it is the rival of my love.
Peace!
Peace!
Peace shall go sleep with Turks and infidels,
Peace have they made with him indeed, my lord.
Peace be with you!
Peace and prosperity! Who is't that calls
Pay with falsehood false exacting,
Paulina! She had one eye declined for the loss of
Pattern in himself to know,
Patience, good Katharina, and Baptista too.
Patience, I pray you; 'twas a fault unwilling.
Patience perforce with wilful choler meeting
Patience is stale, and I am weary of it.
Patience is for poltroons, such as he:
Patience awhile, you'll hear the belly's answer.
Past the mid season.
Past and to come, that you do change this purpose,
Pass'd over to the end they were created,
Pass no further.
Partly for that her promised proportions
Partake to every one. I, an old turtle,
Part, fools!
Part us, Northumberland; I toward the north,
Part of your cares you give me with your crown.
Pardon, old father, my mistaking eyes,
Pardon, my lord; I will not show my face
Pardon, master;
Pardon, madam:
Pardon, good Mercutio, my business was great; and in
Pardon, dear father.
Pardon, I pray thee, for my mad mistaking.
Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own,
Pardon me, noble lord:
Pardon me, madam: little joy have I
Pardon me, lords, 'tis the first time that ever
Pardon me, if you please; if not, I, pleased
Pardon me, good father; it is against my oath.
Pardon me, Margaret; pardon me, sweet son:
Pardon me, God, I knew not what I did!
Pardon me, Edward, I will make amends:
Pardon it;
Pardon is still the nurse of second woe:
Pardon is all the suit I have in hand.
Pale, pale as ashes, all bedaub'd in blood,
Pale trembling coward, there I throw my gage,
Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster!

Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt,
Oxford, how haps it, in this smooth discourse,
Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster!
Owe and succeed thy weakness.
Overdone's own house, for here be many of her old
Over the glittering helmet of my foe!
Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self!
Out--
Out, you rogue! you pluck my foot awry:
Out, you green-sickness carrion! out, you baggage!
Out, devil! I remember them too well:
Out, alas!
Out!
Out upon you! what a man are you!
Out upon him! prig, for my life, prig: he haunts
Out three years old.
Out on you, owls! nothing but songs of death?
Out on her, hilding!
Out of thy sleep. What is it thou didst say?
Out of thy garments.
Out of their saddles into the dirt; and thereby
Out of the dukedom and confer fair Milan
Out of the chamber with her! Were I a tyrant,
Out of my sight! thou dost infect my eyes.
Out of my files, his projects to accomplish,
Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.
Out of his charity, being then appointed
Out of her favour, where I am in love.
Ourselves, our wives, and children, on our knees,
Ourselves to be the slaves of chance and flies
Ourself and Bushy, Bagot here and Green
Ours of true zeal and deep integrity.
Our wish, which side should win: for either thou
Our whole city is much bound to him.
Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast,
Our very priests must become mockers, if they shall
Our uncle York lord governor of England;
Our trusty friend, unless I be deceived.
Our treasures seized, our soldiers put to flight,
Our tradesmen with in their shops and going
Our town of Cicester in Gloucestershire;
Our title to the crown and only claim
Our swifter composition.
Our substitutes at home shall have blank charters;
Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare,
Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings,
Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter.
Our spoils he kick'd at,
Our sorrow with our comfort.
Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change,
Our soldiers', like the night-owl's lazy flight,
Our slaughter'd friends the tackles; what of these?
Our sighs and they shall lodge the summer corn,
Our shame perpetual. Once a day I'll visit
Our scouts have found the adventure very easy:
Our scene is alter'd from a serious thing,
Our rustic garden's barren; and I care not
Our ranks are broke, and ruin follows us:
Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor;
Our purpose to them: and to our noble consul
Our prayers to the gods, which is a comfort
Our prayers do out-pray his; then let them have
Our praises are our wages: you may ride's
Our people and our peers are both misled,
Our part therein we banish with yourselves--
Our old and faithful friend, we are glad to see you.
Our musty superfluity. See, our best elders.
Our most disloyal lady, for, as she hath
Our lands, our lives and all are Bolingbroke's,
Our knees shall kneel till to the ground they grow:
Our instruments to melancholy bells,
Our holy lives must win a new world's crown,
Our haste from hence is of so quick condition
Our hap is loss, our hope but sad despair;
Our guider, come; to the Roman camp conduct us.
Our greatest friends attend us.
Our gentry than our parents' noble names,
Our former hatred, so thrive I and mine!
Our forceful instigation? Our prerogative
Our fine musician groweth amorous.
Our fatherless distress was left unmoan'd;
Our fair appointments may be well perused.
Our enemy is banish'd! he is gone! Hoo! hoo!
Our dukedom till God please to send the rest.
Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.
Our doubts are traitors
Our doctors say this is no month to bleed.
Our cousin Hereford and fell Mowbray fight:
Our coronation: lords, prepare yourselves.
Our corn's to reap, for yet our tithe's to sow.
Our contract celebrated.
Our comfort in the country. We must find
Our city's institutions, and the terms
Our certain death: therefore it is decreed
Our business is not unknown to the senate; they have
Our bruised arms hung up for monuments;
Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse,
Our battles join'd, and both sides fiercely fought:
Our baleful news, and at each word's deliverance
Our army's in the field
Our army is ready; come, we'll after them.
Our archers shall be placed in the midst
Our ancient word of courage, fair Saint George,
Our aery buildeth in the cedar's top,
Our aediles smote? ourselves resisted? Come.
Our Romeo hath not been in bed to-night.
Our Rome will cast upon thee.
Our Rome hath such a soldier.'
Our Perdita is found.
Our Earl of Warwick, Edward's greatest friend.
Order the trial, marshal, and begin.
Or, with the rest, where is your darling Rutland?
Or, wanting that, with tears distill'd by moans:
Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness
Or, like obedient subjects, follow him
Or, if you'ld ask, remember this before:
Or, if you show your face, you must not speak.
Or, if you do not, make the bridal bed
Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self,
Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love,
Or, if sour woe delights in fellowship
Or, if she be accused in true report,
Or, if not so, until the sun be set:
Or, if misfortune miss the first career,
Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.
Or, if he do, it needs must be by stealth.
Or, if I live, is it not very like,
Or, he that slew her brothers and her uncles?
Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave the foe
Or, by the affection that now guides me most,
Or, by Saint Paul, I'll strike thee to my foot,
Or, being open, put into his hands
Or wring redress from you. Hear me, O hear me, here!
Or wrath or craft may get him.
Or worthily, as a good subject should,
Or with the clamorous report of war
Or with pale beggar-fear impeach my height
Or with an outstretch'd throat I'll tell the world aloud
Or wilt thou sleep? we'll have thee to a couch
Or wilt thou ride? thy horses shall be trapp'd,
Or whether that the body public be
Or whether he be 'scaped away or no
Or whether 'twas report of her success;
Or when you waked, so waked as if you slept.
Or what you will command me will I do,
Or what is worst will follow.
Or what is now received: I witness to
Or wallow naked in December snow
Or walk in thievish ways; or bid me lurk
Or to their own perdition.
Or to dispraise my lord with that same tongue
Or thou wert born a fool. Camillo's flight,
Or thou goest to the orange or mill.
Or those eyes shut, that make thee answer 'I.'
Or thee? or thee? or any of your faction?
Or that we would, against the form of law,
Or that the resolute acting of your blood
Or that I could forget what I have been,
Or than for strength and safety of our country.
Or stronger for your need.
Or stones whose rates are either rich or poor
Or sound so base a parle, my teeth shall tear
Or something hath the nothing that I grieve:
Or so devote to Aristotle's cheques
Or shut me nightly in a charnel-house,
Or shall we play the wantons with our woes,
Or shall we on without a apology?
Or shall we on the helmets of our foes
Or shall we beat the stones about thine ears?
Or shall they last, and we rejoice in them?
Or shall I send my daughter Kate to you?
Or shall I come to you at evening mass?
Or seven fair branches springing from one root:
Or seeming so in skill, cannot or will not
Or seem so craftily; and that's not good.
Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway,
Or rudely visit them in parts remote,
Or pile ten hills on the Tarpeian rock,
Or of the deadly seven, it is the least.
Or nourish'd him as I did with my blood,
Or not remember what I must be now!
Or not my father's. For I cannot be
Or never trust to what my tongue can do
Or never be so noble as a consul,
Or never after look me in the face:
Or my true heart with treacherous revolt
Or my shamed life in his dishonour lies:
Or my divine soul answer it in heaven.
Or more than common fear of Clifford's rigour,
Or modest Dian circled with her nymphs,
Or manage it to part these men with me.
Or lowly factor for another's gain;
Or lose mine arm fort: thou hast beat me out
Or live in peace abandon'd and despised!
Or like an idle thresher with a flail,
Or like a cunning instrument cased up,
Or let us stand to our authority,
Or let us lose it. We do here pronounce,
Or let me die, to look on death no more!
Or lambs pursued by hunger-starved wolves.
Or lace for your cape,
Or it hath drawn me rather. But 'tis gone.
Or is the adder better than the eel,
Or in thy piteous heart plant thou thine ear;
Or in my cell there would she kill herself.
Or in his emmence that fills it up,
Or ill-beseeming beast in seeming both!
Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won,
Or if of grief, being altogether had,
Or if not so, then here I hit it right,
Or if it be, 'tis with false sorrow's eye,
Or how stolen from the dead.
Or hoop his body more with thy embraces,
Or hollowly put on.
Or hew my way out with a bloody axe.
Or here or elsewhere to the furthest verge
Or hand of man hath done; therefore I keep it
Or hailstone in the sun. Your virtue is
Or had he 'scaped, methinks we should have heard
Or from the all that are took something good,
Or fortune given me measure of revenge.
Or felt that pain which I did for him once,
Or ere I journey to your father's house.
Or else you would not have bestow'd the heir
Or else you like not of my company.
Or else you get no beef of Grumio.
Or else you famish; that's a threefold death.
Or else thou diest to-morrow.
Or else thou art suborn'd against his honour
Or else new form'd 'em; having both the key
Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.
Or else my heart concealing it will break,
Or else it would have gall'd his surly nature,
Or else his head's assurance is but frail.
Or else he never would compare between.
Or else he must not only die the death,
Or else for ever be confixed here,
Or else depart; here all eyes gaze on us.
Or else come after: I'll away before.
Or else beshrew them both.
Or else be impudently negative,
Or else a hovering temporizer, that
Or earth, gape open wide and eat him quick,
Or docks, or mallows.
Or do I dream? or have I dream'd till now?
Or die renowned by attempting it.
Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.
Or did he make the jest against his will?
Or dedicate his beauty to the sun.
Or daring-hardy as to touch the lists,
Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite
Or chivalrous design of knightly trial:
Or by the father there were none at all;
Or by the break of day disguised from hence:
Or by his foe surprised at unawares:
Or butchers killing flies.
Or breed upon our absence; that may blow
Or both dissemble deeply their affections:
Or blessed was't we did?
Or bitterly to speak in your reproof.
Or bide the mortal fortune of the field?
Or bid me go into a new-made grave
Or bend one wrinkle on my sovereign's face.
Or be accused of folly. I shall tell you
Or bathed thy growing with our heated bloods.
Or as thy father and his father did,
Or as the south to the septentrion.
Or as a moat defensive to a house,
Or as a bear, encompass'd round with dogs,
Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen.
Or any other ground inhabitable,
Or any he the proudest of thy sort.
Or any creeping venom'd thing that lives!
Or am I mad, hearing him talk of Juliet,
Or all will fall in broil.
Or all or lose his hire.
Or a half-moon made with a pen.
Or Signior Gremio, you, know any such,
Or Jove for's power to thunder. His heart's his mouth:
Or I'll be buried in the king's highway,
Or I with grief and extreme age shall perish
Or I will fill the house with armed men,
Or I will drag thee on a hurdle thither.
Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yard
Or I shall faint. A plague o' both your houses!
Or I my life.
Or I mistake you: O, would her name were Grace!
Or I am much deceived, cuckolds ere now;
Or Ethiopian's tooth, or the fann'd
Or Edward's soft and pitiful, like mine
Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood,
Or Cytherea's breath; pale primroses
Opposing laws with strokes and here defying
Opposed, as it must be, by the power of the king:
Oppose against their wills.
Opinion that so sticks on Marcius shall
Open their congeal'd mouths and bleed afresh!
Open the tomb, lay me with Juliet.
Open the gates; we are King Henry's friends.
Open Thy gate of mercy, gracious God!
Only, this one: Lord Angelo is precise;
Only, good master, while we do admire

Only make trial what your love can do

Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows
Only fair speech.

One that made means to come by what he hath,
One that hath ever been God's enemy:

One seven-night longer.
One rich enough to be Petruchio's wife,

One on 's father's moods.
One of these two must be necessities,
One of these is true:
One of these days; and then you'ld wanton with us,
One of them you shall be.
One of the prettiest touches of all and that which
One of our souls had wander'd in the air.
One of our order, to associate me,
One of our convent, and his confessor,

One more, most welcome, makes my number more.
One kiss shall stop our mouths, and dumbly part;
One jot of ceremony.
One i' the neck, and two i' the thigh,--there's
One heaved a-high, to be hurl'd down below;
One grave shall be for both: upon them shall
One flourishing branch of his most royal root,
One fire drives out one fire; one nail, one nail;
One fairer than my love! the all-seeing sun
One desperate grief cures with another's languish:
One day too late, I fear me, noble lord,
One Ragozine, a most notorious pirate,
One Isabel, a sister, desires access to you.

Of your great danger.

Of woeful ages long ago betid;
Of whom you seem to have so tender care?

Of who she but bid follow.

Of what you promised me.
Of what we chance to sentence.
Of what that want might ruin.
Of what lies heavy to't.

Of what is to be dreaded.
Of what is past.
Of what degree soever, with his brother.
Of watery Neptune, is now bound in with shame,
Of us too much beloved. Let us be clear'd
Of unrelenting Clifford and the queen,
Of tyranny and will ignoble make you,
Of twenty men, it would dispatch you straight.
Of trembling winter, the fairest
Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal.
Of thy deep duty more impression show
Of thy adverse pernicious enemy:
Of threescore and two years; a silly time
Of thousands that had struck anointed kings
Of those that lawless and incertain thought
Of those physicians that first wounded thee:
Of this sir-reverence love, wherein thou stick'st
Of this new marriage with the Lady Grey?
Of this most wise rebellion, thou go'st foremost:
Of this most grievous guilty murder done!
Of this make no conclusion, lest you say
Of this hard world, my ragged prison walls,
Of this fair couple, meets he on the way
Of this diseased opinion, and betimes;
Of this day's journey, and from nine till twelve
Of these supposed-evils, to give me leave,
Of these fair edifices 'fore my wars
Of these Plantagenets, Henry and Edward,
Of their own choice: one's Junius Brutus,
Of their breath only!
Of their best trust; o'er them Aufidius,
Of thee, my dear one, thee, my daughter, who
Of thee thyself and all thy complices,
Of the young prince, whose honourable thoughts,
Of the young prince your son: send straight for him

Of the whole dungy earth.

Of the whole body. The belly answer'd--

Of the salt deep,
Of the queen's speed, is gone.

Of the king's ship
Of the grave wearers. O, the sacrifice!
Of the all-building law; and that there were
Of the Lord Bonville on your new wife's son,
Of that wide gap, since it is in my power
Of that unsatiate Edward, noble York
Of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound:
Of that there's none, or little.
Of that sweet way I was in to despair!
Of that report which I so oft have heard.
Of that proud man that did usurp his back?
Of that integrity which should become't,
Of ten times double gain of happiness.
Of sweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford slain:
Of sulphurous roaring the most mighty Neptune
Of such possessions and so high esteem,
Of such as have before endured the like.
Of stuff'd sufficiency: now from the oracle
Of stronger earth than others. My mother bows;
Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled;
Of sprites and goblins.
Of sorrow or of joy?
Of some strange nature, letting it there stand
Of sky-aspiring and ambitious thoughts,
Of shame seen through thy country, speed
Of sacred chastity and of promise-breach
Of reasonable affairs? is he not stupid
Of prey that keep upon't.
Of present death.
Of pity, not revenge!
Of palsied eld; and when thou art old and rich,
Of outward order: this we came not to,
Of our so frank donation. Well, what then?
Of our proceedings here: on the marketplace,
Of our own power: what think you of it?
Of our most gracious mistress.
Of our great action: therefore shall he die,

Of our design. He bears himself more proudlier,
Of one I danced withal.
Of officer and office, set all hearts i' the state
Of noisome musty chaff: he said 'twas folly,
Of noble blood in this declining land.
Of noble Richard! then true noblesse would
Of no more soul nor fitness for the world
Of no allowance to your bosom's truth.
Of neither, girl:
Of necessary fitness?
Of my young play-fellow.
Of my success.

Of my lord general.

Of my Lord Hastings' late imprisonment.
Of much less value is my company
Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him
Of mortal breathing: seize it, if thou darest.
Of more strong link asunder than can ever
Of middle summer, and I think they are given
Of love?
Of love between your daughter and himself:
Of limping winter treads, even such delight
Of laughing with a sigh?--a note infallible
Of its right father. Blossom, speed thee well!
Of its own kind, all foison, all abundance,
Of ill-shaped fishes; and about his shelves
Of hostile arms! myself myself confound!
Of honourable reckoning are you both;
Of homage and I know not how much tribute,
Of holy reverence; who, I cannot learn.
Of his most sovereign name; consider little
Of his ill-ta'en suspicion! Come, Camillo;
Of his demerits rob Cominius.
Of his bright passage to the occident.
Of his bones are coral made;
Of him that did not ask, but mock, bestow
Of her awaking, here untimely lay
Of healths five-fathom deep; and then anon
Of head-piece extraordinary? lower messes
Of happy holding her.
Of greater sums than I have promised.
Of great Apollo's priest; and that, since then,
Of gracious order, late come from the See
Of government the properties to unfold,
Of good old Abraham! Lords appellants,
Of good and bad, that makes and unfolds error,
Of good Polixenes; and my ground to do't
Of golden sovereignty; acquaint the princess
Of golden metal that must round my brow
Of general ignorance,--it must omit
Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure.
Of force enough to bid his brother battle;
Of fire and water, when their thundering shock
Of fair demesnes, youthful, and nobly train'd,
Of excellent witchcraft, who of force must know
Of every wind that blows.
Of ever angry bears: it was a torment
Of either, madam.
Of dreaded justice, but on the ministers
Of double-fatal yew against thy state;
Of disobedient opposition
Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep:
Of dear import, and the neglecting it
Of damned witchcraft, and that have prevail'd
Of contradiction: being once chafed, he cannot
Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life.
Of civil wounds plough'd up with neighbours' sword;
Of celebration of that nuptial which
Of capital treason we arrest you here.
Of burning youth.
Of burning Rome.
Of breaking honesty--horsing foot on foot?
Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades,
Of boundless tongue, who late hath beat her husband
Of both the Sicils and Jerusalem,
Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.
Of blind forgetfulness and dark oblivion.
Of blessed sanctuary! not for all this land
Of being tyrannous, since we so openly
Of any thing the image tell me that
Of any point in't shall not only be
Of an one pain, save for a night of groans
Of an old tear that is not wash'd off yet:
Of all thy suitors, here I charge thee, tell
Of all the world I loved and to him put
Of all the voices that we have procured
Of all the under fiends. But if so be
Of all the trades in Rome. Look, I am going:
Of all the days of the year, upon that day:
Of all that hear me, and my near'st of kin
Of all professors else, make proselytes
Of all my buried ancestors are packed:
Of all mad matches never was the like.
Of all encertainties himself commended,
Of a strange fever. Upon his mere request,
Of a poor worm. Thy best of rest is sleep,
Of a poor 'pothecary, and therewithal
Of a despised life closed in my breast
Of Tybalt deaf to peace, but that he tilts
Of Sycorax, toads, beetles, bats, light on you!
Of Ragozine, more like to Claudio?
Of Pisa, sir; son to Vincentio.
Of Phoebus' burning kisses: such a pother
Of Naples and of Milan, what strange fish
Of Marcius?
Of Mantua.
Of Mantua, sir? marry, God forbid!
Of King Polixenes, it should here be laid,
Of Essex, Norfolk, Suffolk, nor of Kent,
Of England's true-anointed lawful king.
Of England's chair, where he is falsely set;
Of Edward's heirs the murderer shall be.
Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.
Of Bolingbroke: their fortunes both are weigh'd:
Of Bolingbroke, covering your fearful land

Obeying with my wind when I do blow,
Obey, and go with me; for thou must die.
Obey the bride, you that attend on her;
Obey and be attentive. Canst thou remember
Obedience bids I should not bid again.

Nor what is mine shall never do thee good:
Nor was not to be equall'd;'--thus your verse
Nor to be seen: my crown is called content:
Nor thou within the compass of my curse.
Nor the prevention of poor Bolingbroke
Nor that is not the lark, whose notes do beat
Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses:
Nor tackle, sail, nor mast; the very rats
Nor showing, as the manner is, his wounds
Nor shall not be the last; like silly beggars
Nor shall appear in Sicilia.
Nor read the secrets in't.
Nor posted off their suits with slow delays;
Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold:
Nor now my scandal, Richard, dost thou hear;
Nor none that live, I hope.
Nor none so bad, but it may well be told.
Nor no without-book prologue, faintly spoke
Nor no such men as you have reckon'd up,
Nor no one here; for curses never pass
Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no title,
Nor night nor day no rest: it is but weakness
Nor never write, regreet, nor reconcile
Nor never needed that I should entreat,
Nor never look upon each other's face;
Nor never by advised purpose meet
Nor need you, on mine honour, have to do
Nor near nor farther off, my gracious lord,
Nor much oppress'd them with great subsidies.
Nor mother, wife, nor England's counted queen.
Nor more can you distinguish of a man
Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass;
Nor is't directly laid to thee, the death
Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me,
Nor in a way so chaste, since my desires
Nor how to use your brothers brotherly,
Nor how to study for the people's welfare,
Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies?
Nor how to be contented with one wife,
Nor here provincial. My business in this state
Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk,
Nor get a messenger to bring it thee,
Nor from the state nor private friends, hereafter
Nor friends nor foes, to me welcome you are:
Nor forward of revenge, though they much err'd:
Nor ever will be ruled.
Nor do I think the man of safe discretion
Nor do I thee: though I did wish him dead,
Nor did you think it folly
Nor dare to know that which I know. O sir!
Nor cowardly in retire: believe me, sirs,
Nor cheque my courage for what they can give,
Nor cheer of mind, that I was wont to have.
Nor can we lie distinguish'd by our faces
Nor can my tongue unload my heart's great burthen;
Nor by the matter which your heart prompts you,
Nor brass nor stone nor parchment bears not one,
Nor bite the lip, as angry wenches will,
Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes,
Nor be grieved: she is of good esteem,
Nor aught so good but strain'd from that fair use
Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part
Nor any of the house of Lancaster?
Nor a musician, as I seem to be;
Nor I; my spirits are nimble.
Nor I.
Nor I.
Nor I.
Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself
Nor I, nor any
Nor I, but stoop with patience to my fortune.
Nor I nor any man that but man is
Nor I no more of his, than you of mine.

NATHANIEL:
Myself, a prince by fortune of my birth,
Myself your loyal servant, your physician,
Myself your loyal servant, or endure
Myself to see the issue.
Myself to be a marvellous proper man.
Myself thus alter'd with 't.
Myself in person will straight follow you.
Myself have often heard him say and swear
Myself disposed to sleep.
Myself disgraced, and the nobility
Myself condemned and myself excused.
Myself and my good cousin Buckingham
Myself am struck in years, I must confess;
Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.
Myself I throw, dread sovereign, at thy foot.
My wretchedness unto a row of pins,
My work hath yet not warm'd me: fare you well:
My words would bandy her to my sweet love,
My words express my purpose.
My words disbench'd you not.
My words are dull; O, quicken them with thine!
My women may be with me; for you see
My will to her consent is but a part;
My wife, sir, whom I detest before heaven and your honour,--
My wife's a hobby-horse, deserves a name
My wife to France: from whence, set forth in pomp,
My wife is slippery? If thou wilt confess,
My wife is nothing; nor nothing have these nothings,
My wife comes foremost; then the honour'd mould
My widow says, thus she conceives her tale.
My weaved-up folly? Gentle Northumberland,
My waters; on the earth, and not on him.
My waned state for Henry's regal crown.
My vouch against you, and my place i' the state,
My voice is now the king's, my looks mine own.
My very worthy cousin, fairly met!
My very friend, hath got his mortal hurt
My unsoil'd name, the austereness of my life,
My uncles both are slain in rescuing me;
My uncle Rivers talk'd how I did grow
My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets!
My trusty servant, well approved in all,
My true love's passion: therefore pardon me,
My true Paulina,
My traffic is sheets; when the kite builds, look to
My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,
My tongue to such a pace:--'Look, sir, my wounds!
My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys
My tongue hath but a heavier tale to say.
My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word;
My tongue cleave to my roof within my mouth
My title's good, and better far than his.
My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice;
My thoughts are minutes; and with sighs they jar
My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks;
My tears gainsay; for every word I speak,
My tale provokes that question. Dear, they durst not,
My sword, I say! Old Montague is come,
My swift command, though I with death and with
My surname, Coriolanus: the painful service,
My subjects for a pair of carved saints
My strong imagination sees a crown
My strength can give you: then no more remains,
My stooping duty tenderly shall show.
My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.
My sovereign, with the loving citizens,
My sovereign mistress clouded so, without
My sovereign liege, no letters; and few words,
My sovereign liege, I do beseech your majesty
My soul to heaven, my blood upon your heads!
My soul the father; and these two beget
My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.
My soul flies through these wounds to seek out Thee.
My sons, God knows what hath bechanced them:
My son is lost and, in my rate, she too,
My son George Stanley is frank'd up in hold:
My sisterly remorse confutes mine honour,
My sighing breast shall be thy funeral bell;
My sceptre for a palmer's walking staff,
My royal father, cheer these noble lords
My revenge properly, my remission lies
My remedy is then, to pluck it out.
My rage is gone;
My queen and son are gone to France for aid;
My quarrel and this English queen's are one.
My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak.
My prisoner? or my guest? by your dread 'Verily,'
My princely father then had wars in France
My pretty cousins, you mistake me much;
My prettiest Perdita!
My present vengeance taken: 'shrew my heart,
My prayers on the adverse party fight;
My praises made thee first a soldier, so,
My power? Alas, I doubt--
My poverty, but not my will, consents.
My plight requires it. Do not weep, good fools;
My pity hath been balm to heal their wounds,
My people did expect my hence departure
My patience here is touch'd. I do perceive
My part thereof that I have done to her.
My parks, my walks, my manors that I had.
My parasite, my soldier, statesman, all:
My other self, my counsel's consistory,
My oracle, my prophet! My dear cousin,
My only love sprung from my only hate!
My oil-dried lamp and time-bewasted light
My nose that bled, or foil'd some debile wretch.--
My noble uncle, do you know the cause?
My noble steed, known to the camp, I give him,
My noble queen, let former grudges pass,
My noble masters, hear me speak.
My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.
My native English, now I must forego:
My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself,
My name is call'd Vincentio; my dwelling Pisa;
My name is Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk;
My name is Caius Marcius, who hath done
My name hath touch'd your ears it is Menenius.
My name be blotted from the book of life,
My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I will back thee.
My mother, and my nurse, that bears me yet!
My mirth it much displeased, but pleased my woe.
My mind will never grant what I perceive
My mind presumes, for his own good and ours.
My mind presageth happy gain and conquest.
My mind is changed, sir, my mind is changed.
My mind hath been as big as one of yours,
My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel.
My mildness hath allay'd their swelling griefs,
My mild entreaty shall not make you guilty.
My mercy dried their water-flowing tears;
My men should call me 'lord:' I am your goodman.
My mate, that's never to be found again,
My master's.
My master knows not but I am gone hence;
My master is grown quarrelsome. I should knock
My marvel and my message. To your court
My manors, rents, revenues I forego;
My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear;
My loving lord, I take my leave of you;
My love, forbear to fawn upon their frowns:
My love till death, my humble thanks, my prayers;
My love as deep; the more I give to thee,
My love and fear glued many friends to thee;
My lords, when you shall know--as in this rage,
My lords, we were forewarned of your coming,
My lords, look where the sturdy rebel sits,
My lords, forbear this talk; here comes the king.
My lords, before it pleased his majesty
My lords, at once: the cause why we are met
My lords of England, let me tell you this:
My lord?
My lord?
My lord?
My lord?
My lord?
My lord?
My lord?
My lord; I do confess I ne'er was married;
My lord: he doth entreat your grace;
My lord.
My lord,--
My lord, your sorrow was too sore laid on,
My lord, your son was gone before I came.
My lord, your promise for the earldom,--
My lord, you told me you would tell the rest,
My lord, you shall o'er-rule my mind for once.
My lord, you nod; you do not mind the play.
My lord, you do me shameful injury,
My lord, wise men ne'er sit and wail their woes,
My lord, will't please you to fall to?
My lord, will't please you pass along?
My lord, whoever journeys to the Prince,
My lord, we'll do it throughly.
My lord, we must entreat the time alone.
My lord, this is one Lucio's information against me.
My lord, this argues conscience in your grace;
My lord, there needs no such apology:
My lord, the mind of Bolingbroke is changed:
My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.
My lord, the enemy is past the marsh
My lord, the army of the Duke of Buckingham--
My lord, stand back, and let the coffin pass.
My lord, some two days since I saw the prince,
My lord, she may be a punk; for many of them are
My lord, no leave take I; for I will ride,
My lord, my answer is--to Lancaster;
My lord, most villanously; believe it.
My lord, in the base court he doth attend
My lord, here comes the rascal I spoke of; here with
My lord, her wits, I fear me, are not firm:
My lord, he fears you mean no good to him.
My lord, he doth deny to come.
My lord, good morrow; good morrow, Catesby:
My lord, dispatch; read o'er these articles.
My lord, cheer up your spirits: our foes are nigh,
My lord, I'll tell my lady you will come.
My lord, I would that Thursday were to-morrow.
My lord, I warrant you we will play our part,
My lord, I must confess I know this woman:
My lord, I like not of this flight of Edward's;
My lord, I know him; 'tis a meddling friar;
My lord, I know a discontented gentleman,
My lord, I hear the Marquis Dorset's fled
My lord, I have from Oxford sent to London
My lord, I had forgot to tell your lordship,
My lord, I dare not: Sir Pierce of Exton, who
My lord, I claim your gift, my due by promise,
My lord, I am more amazed at his dishonour
My lord, 'tis nothing.
My lord, 'tis but begun.
My lord,
My lord,
My lord,
My lord,
My lord,
My lord,
My lord's almost so far transported that
My lord!
My lord!
My lord!
My lord the king, the king!
My lord should to the heavens be contrary,
My lord protector needs will have it so.
My lord of Salisbury, we have stay'd ten days,
My lord of Ely!
My lord it shall be done.
My lord and you were then at Mantua:--
My lord and sovereign, and thy vowed friend,
My lord and husband!
My lord Sebastian,
My life, sir! how, I pray? for that goes hard.
My life were better ended by their hate,
My life thou shalt command, but not my shame:
My life stands in the level of your dreams,
My life may last to answer.
My life and services.
My liege, the wound that bred this meeting here
My liege, the Duke of Buckingham is taken;
My liege, one word.
My liege, old Gaunt commends him to your majesty.
My liege, it is young Henry, earl of Richmond.
My liege, in Kent the Guildfords are in arms;
My liege, I'll knock once more to summon them.
My liberty.
My lessons make no music in three parts.
My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now.
My legs can keep no measure in delight,
My leash unwillingly.
My last good deed was to entreat his stay:
My language! heavens!
My land amounts not to so much in all:
My ladies both, good day to you.
My joy of liberty is half eclipsed.
My intercession likewise steads my foe.
My inch of taper will be burnt and done,
My ill suspicion. This is your son-in-law,
My husband lost his life to get the crown;
My husband lives, that Tybalt would have slain;
My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven;
My husband bids me; now I will unmask.
My husband and my lord, my lord and husband;
My household stuff, my field, my barn,
My house and welcome on their pleasure stay.
My horse, my ox, my ass, my any thing;
My horse to yours, no.
My holy sir, none better knows than you
My heart, sweet boy, shall be thy sepulchre,
My heart will sigh when I miscall it so,
My heart will be a burthen to me. Leave me,
My heart this covenant makes, my hand thus seals it.
My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.
My heart is not confederate with my hand.
My heart is great; but it must break with silence,
My heart for anger burns; I cannot brook it.
My heart as great, my reason haply more,
My hazards still have been your solace: and
My hate to Marcius: where I find him, were it
My haste may not admit it;
My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry;
My hand is ready; may it do him ease.
My hair doth stand on end to hear her curses.
My guilt be on my head, and there an end.
My great profaneness 'gainst thine oracle!
My grave is like to be my wedding bed.
My grandam told me he was murdered there.
My grained ash an hundred times hath broke
My gracious uncle--
My gracious uncle, let me know my fault:
My gracious sovereign?
My gracious sovereign, on the western coast
My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire,
My gracious sovereign, my most loving liege!
My gracious silence, hail!
My gracious lord,--
My gracious lord, here in the parliament
My gracious lord, I'll tell him what you say.
My gracious lord, I tender you my service,
My gracious lord, I come but for mine own.
My gracious lord, Henry your foe is taken,
My gracious lord,
My gracious liege, this too much lenity
My gracious lady, go;
My gracious father, by your kingly leave,
My gorgeous palace for a hermitage,
My good lords both, with all the heed I may.
My good Camillo,
My gentle Marcius, worthy Caius, and
My general cares not for you. Back, I say, go; lest
My gay apparel for an almsman's gown,
My friends of noble touch, when I am forth,
My friend, I spy some pity in thy looks:
My friend Polixenes: which had been done,
My fortunes to your service, which are here
My fortunes and my friends at stake required
My foreward shall be drawn out all in length,
My foot my tutor? Put thy sword up, traitor;
My first son.
My fingers itch. Wife, we scarce thought us blest
My figured goblets for a dish of wood,
My fear to hope, my sorrows unto joys,
My favour here begins to warp. Not speak?
My father, being the Earl of Warwick's man,
My father's of a better nature, sir,
My father's loss, the weakness which I feel,
My father's goods are all distrain'd and sold,
My father's death--
My father's bears more toward the market-place;
My father will grant precious things as trifles.
My father of this business.
My father hath a power; inquire of him
My father dead, my fortune lives for me;
My father came untimely to his death?
My father and my grandfather were kings,
My father Capulet will have it so;
My fan, Peter.
My falcon now is sharp and passing empty;
My fair rose wither: yet look up, behold,
My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome,
My eye's too quick, my heart o'erweens too much,
My evils conjured to remembrance and
My elder brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere,
My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words
My dukedom to a beggarly denier,
My dreams presage some joyful news at hand:
My dismal scene I needs must act alone.
My death's sad tale may yet undeaf his ear.
My dear?
My dear-loved cousin, and my dearer lord?
My dear wife's estimate, her womb's increase,
My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul.
My daughter he hath wedded: I will die,
My daughter Katharina is to be married:
My dangerous cousin, let your mother in:
My damned son, which thy two sweet sons smother'd.
My dainty duck, my dear-a?
My dagger, little cousin? with all my heart.
My crown is in my heart, not on my head;
My crown I am; but still my griefs are mine:
My country's good with a respect more tender,
My conscience tells me he is lawful king.
My conscience hath a thousand several tongues,
My conceal'd lady to our cancell'd love?
My comfort is that heaven will take our souls
My child? away with't! Even thou, that hast
My child is yet a stranger in the world;
My charity is outrage, life my shame
My chamber-councils, wherein, priest-like, thou
My careless father fondly gave away'?
My care is loss of care, by old care done;
My cake is dough; but I'll in among the rest,
My cabin where I lay; thrice bow'd before me,
My business, sir, is to the king.
My business is a word or two with Claudio.
My brother's love, the devil, and my rage.
My brother was too careless of his charge.
My brother slew no man; his fault was thought,
My brother did love Juliet,
My brother and thy uncle, call'd Antonio--
My brother Montague shall post to London:
My brother Gloucester, plain well-meaning soul,
My breast can better brook thy dagger's point
My brave spirit!
My brain I'll prove the female to my soul,
My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently.
My bounty is as boundless as the sea,
My bosom's lord sits lightly in his throne;
My books and instruments shall be my company,
My body up to shame.
My body shall make good upon this earth,
My blood, my want of strength, my sick heart shows.
My blood for your rude brawls doth lie a-bleeding;
My blemishes in them, and so still think of
My birth-place hate I, and my love's upon
My best beloved and approved friend,
My best and freshest men; served his designments
My best Camillo! We must disguise ourselves.
My banquet is to close our stomachs up,
My back o' t' other side,--O, my back, my back!
My babes were destined to a fairer death,
My ashes, as the phoenix, may bring forth
My affections
My acts, decrees, and statutes I deny:
My absolute power and place here in Vienna,
My absence doth neglect no great designs,
My Lord, I have consider'd in my mind
My Lord!
My Lord of York will still be cross in talk:
My Lord of Westminster, be it your charge
My Lord of Warwick, hear me but one word:
My Lord of Surrey, why look you so sad?
My Lord of Somerset, what youth is that,
My Lord of Somerset, at my request,
My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon,
My Lord of Norfolk,--
My Lord of Hereford, my message is to you.
My Lord of Hereford here, whom you call king,
My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days
My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne
My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory
My Lord Northumberland, see them dispatch'd.
My Lord Fitzwater, I do remember well
My Lord Aumerle, is Harry Hereford arm'd?
My Lord Aumerle, I know your daring tongue
My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, 'tis she
Mutually.
Muster'd my soldiers, gather'd flocks of friends,
Must, as a foreign recreant, be led
Must to Corioli back: send us to Rome
Must these have voices, that can yield them now
Must strike her sail and learn awhile to serve
Must stead us all and me amongst the rest,
Must needs appear offence.
Must it be violent, and as he does conceive
Must it be great, and as his person's mighty,
Must help you more than you are hurt by me.
Must he needs die?
Must have their voices; neither will they bate
Must have a word anon. Lay hold on him.
Must give this cur the lie: and his own notion--
Must get a father, call'd 'supposed Vincentio;'
Must gently be preserved, cherish'd, and kept:
Must either punish me, not being believed,
Must die to-morrow! O injurious love,
Must climb a bird's nest soon when it is dark:
Must by us both be spent most preciously.
Must by the roots be hewn up yet ere night.
Must bear my beating to his grave--shall join
Must be my convoy in the secret night.
Must all determine here?
Must I with base tongue give my noble heart
Must I then do't to them?
Must I receive, whose every word deserves
Must I not serve a long apprenticehood
Must I go show them my unbarbed sconce?
Must I do so? and must I ravel out
Must Edward fall, which peril heaven forfend!
Musicians, O, musicians, 'Heart's ease, Heart's
Musician:
Music, awake her; strike!
Music and poesy use to quicken you;
Murdering impossibility, to make
Murder, stem murder, in the direst degree;
Murder'd her kinsman. O, tell me, friar, tell me,
Murder thy breath in the middle of a word,
Murder her brothers, and then marry her!
Mum.
Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty;
Much more to be thus opposite with heaven,
Much more than death: do not say 'banishment.'
Much more a shrew of thy impatient humour.
Much is your sorrow; mine ten times so much.
Much comfort in't; says 'My poor prisoner,
Much about cock-shut time, from troop to troop
Mowbray, impartial are our eyes and ears:
Moved! in good time: let him that moved you hither
Move them no more by crossing their high will.
Mounted upon a hot and fiery steed
Mount, mount, my soul! thy seat is up on high;
Mount you, my lord; towards Berwick post amain:
Mother, I am going to the market-place;
Most wrongfully accused your substitute,
Most worthy madam,
Most willingly;
Most welcome!
Most valour, spoke not for them: the accusation
Most true, if ever truth were pregnant by
Most sweet voices!
Most sure, the goddess
Most strange, but yet most truly, will I speak:
Most sorry, you have broken from his liking
Most royal sir, from thence; from him, whose daughter
Most reverend and grave elders, to desire
Most ponderous and substantial things!
Most piteous to be wild, I have dispatch'd in post
Most palates theirs. They choose their magistrate,
Most notedly, sir.
Most noble sir,
Most noble sir,
Most miserable hour that e'er time saw
Most mighty sovereign,
Most mighty prince, my Lord Northumberland,
Most mighty liege, and my companion peers,
Most manifest, and not denied by himself.
Most lamentable day, most woful day,
Most incident to maids; bold oxlips and
Most ignorant of what he's most assured,
Most holy sir, I thank you.
Most goddess-like prank'd up: but that our feasts
Most dignifies the haver: if it be,
Most detestable death, by thee beguil'd,
Most dear'st! my collop! Can thy dam?--may't be?--
Most dangerously you have with him prevail'd,
Most bounteous sir,
Most audible, even from his proper tongue,
Mortality and mercy in Vienna
Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy.
Moreover, urge his hateful luxury
More, she's a traitor and Camillo is
More worthier than their voices. They know the corn
More worth than any man; men, that she is
More wonderful, when angels are so angry.
More widows in them of this business' making
More welcome is the stroke of death to me
More torches here! Come on then, let's to bed.
More to know
More than your lord's departure weep not: more's not seen;
More than you doubt the change on't, that prefer
More than with ruthless waves, with sands and rocks.
More than with parting from my lord the king.
More than was ever man's, I would not prize them
More than to Richmond?  for the selfsame heaven
More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot.
More than thou hast, and with it joy thy life;
More than the nature of a brother's love!
More than the instant army we can make,
More than the infant that is born to-night
More than the common blocks: not noted, is't,
More than prince of cats, I can tell you. O, he is
More than our brother is our chastity.
More than my dancing soul doth celebrate
More than my brother: 'Ay,' quoth my uncle
More than my body's parting with my soul!
More than mistress of
More than it is ere foul sin gathering head
More than his singularity, he goes
More than a wild exposture to each chance
More than I seem, and less than I was born to:
More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue
More than I have said, loving countrymen,
More straining on for plucking back, not following
More sins for this forgiveness prosper may.
More rich for what they yielded.
More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable:
More pleasant, pithy and effectual,
More pity that the eagle should be mew'd,
More penitence than done trespass: at the last,
More of him anon. There is written in your brow,
More nor less to others paying
More noble blows than ever thou wise words;
More monstrous standing by: whereof I reckon
More mild, but yet more harmful, kind in hatred:
More light, you knaves; and turn the tables up,
More light and light; more dark and dark our woes!
More learned than the ears--waving thy head,
More honourable state, more courtship lives
More homely than thy state. For thee, fond boy,
More holy and profound, than mine own life,
More health and happiness betide my liege
More hath he spent in peace than they in wars.
More grave and wrinkled than the aims and ends
More free than he is jealous.
More fit to do another such offence
More fierce and more inexorable far
More fearful, is deliver'd.
More direful hap betide that hated wretch,
More cruel to your good report than grateful
More criminal in thee than it,--so thou
More bound to 's mother; yet here he lets me prate
More bitterly could I expostulate,
More are men's ends mark'd than their lives before:
More after our commandment than as guided
Mopsa must be your mistress: marry, garlic,
Montague, Montague, for Lancaster!
Montague's men from the wall, and thrust his maids
Money's a medler.
Monday, my lord,
Monday! ha, ha! Well, Wednesday is too soon,
Mock not my senseless conjuration, lords:
Misused ere used, by time misused o'erpast.
Mistrust it not: for, sure, AEacides
Mistress, your father prays you leave your books
Mistress, what's your opinion of your sister?
Mistress, what cheer?
Mistress, we have.
Mistress, how mean you that?
Mistress! what, mistress! Juliet! fast, I warrant her, she:
Mistress Overdone.
Mistress Kate Keepdown was with child by him in the
Mistress Elbow, being, as I say, with child, and
Mistress Bianca, bless you with such grace
Misthink the king and not be satisfied!
Mistake not, uncle, further than you should.
Mistake no more: I am not Licio,
Mistake me not; I speak but as I find.
Mistake me not--to save my life, for if
Mistake me not, my lord; 'tis not my meaning
Mist-like, infold me from the search of eyes.
Misshapen in the conduct of them both,
Misguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman,
Misconstrue us in him and wail his death.
Miscarried by my fault, let my old life
Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms!
Minion, thou liest. Is't not Hortensio?
Mine, such as fill my heart with unhoped joys.
Mine, full of sorrow and heart's discontent.
Mine were the very cipher of a function,
Mine own, nor any thing to any, if
Mine own desert.
Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter
Mine innocency and Saint George to thrive!
Mine honour lives when his dishonour dies,
Mine honour is my life; both grow in one:
Mine honour for his truth: who being so heighten'd,
Mine eyes to sweat compassion. But, good sir,
Mine eyes are full of tears, I cannot see:
Mine enemy has more power.
Mine ears against your suits are stronger than
Mine ear is open and my heart prepared;
Mine ear hath tempted judgment to desire.
Mine boy? not till King Henry be dead.
Mine arms about that body, where against
Might you dispense with your leisure, I would by and
Might thus have stood begetting wonder as
Might there not be a charity in sin
Might stop our countryman.
Might in the times to come have ta'en revenge,
Might in the ground be closed up in rest!
Might have found easy fines: but there to end
Might from our quiet confines fright fair peace
Might come to me again. Who's there?
Might I but through my prison once a day
Might I a son and daughter now have look'd on,
Mi perdonato, gentle master mine,
Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower,
Methought their souls, whose bodies Richard murder'd,
Methought the souls of all that I had murder'd
Methought that Gloucester stumbled; and, in falling,
Methought he bore him in the thickest troop
Methought I saw a thousand fearful wrecks;
Methought I had; and often did I strive
Methinks, 'tis prize enough to be his son.
Methinks thou speak'st not well.
Methinks these peers of France should smile at that.
Methinks the truth should live from age to age,
Methinks the power that Edward hath in field
Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we
Methinks he looks as though he were in love:
Methinks a woman of this valiant spirit
Methinks a father
Methinks King Richard and myself should meet
Methinks I so should term them, and the reverence
Methinks I see thee, now thou art below,
Methinks I see him stamp thus, and call thus:
Methinks I play as I have seen them do
Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum,
Methinks I am a prophet new inspired

Merry or sad shall't be?
Merely, my lord.
Merely in hate, 'gainst any of us all,
Merely awry: when he did love his country,
Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd:
Mercy is not itself, that oft looks so;
Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.
Mercutio, thou consort'st with Romeo,--
Mercutio's kinsman, noble County Paris!
Menenius, you are known well enough too.
Menenius ever, ever.
Mended again. The matter; proceed.
Men's eyes were made to look, and let them gaze;
Men well inclined to hear what thou command'st:
Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes,
Men judge by the complexion of the sky
Men give like gods; but when they weep and kneel,
Men for their sons, wives for their husbands,
Men are but gilded loam or painted clay.
Melting with tenderness and kind compassion
Meet on the market-place. We'll attend you there:
Meet me within this hour at Baynard's Castle.
Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe:
Measureless liar, thou hast made my heart
Measured to look upon you; whom he loves--
Measure our confines with such peaceful steps?
Measure for measure must be answered.
Meantime, this deep disgrace in brotherhood
Meantime, have patience.
Meantime, but think how I may do thee good,
Meantime, God grants that we have need of you:
Meaning, to court'sy.
Meaning to keep her closely at my cell,
Meaning the king at Pomfret. Come, let's go:
Mean time let this defend my loyalty,
Me too, let me go thither.
Me they shall feel while I am able to stand: and
Me shall you find ready and willing
Me seemeth good, that, with some little train,
Me rather had my heart might feel your love
Me cause to wail but teachest me the way
Me and thy crying self.
Mayor:
Mayor:
Mayor:
May your grace speak of it?
May yet ere night yield both my life and them
May well abate the over-merry spleen
May walk again: if such thing be, thy mother
May this, almost a miracle, be done?
May think anon it moves.
May they perceive's intent! He will require them,
May these same instruments, which you profane,
May that ground gape and swallow me alive,
May tear a passage through the flinty ribs
May suffer alteration, on mine honour,
May stand in number, though in reckoning none,
May show like all yourself.
May show her duty and make known her love?'
May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world!
May seem as shy, as grave, as just, as absolute
May say 'This mercy we have show'd;' the Romans,
May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.
May not one speak?
May not be punish'd with my thwarting stars,
May move your hearts to pity if you mark him.
May make against the house of Lancaster.
May know if you remain upon this island;
May it please your highness to resolve me now;
May it please you, lords, to grant the commons' suit.
May in the sworn twelve have a thief or two
May hourly trample on their sovereign's head;
May hold together: on her frights and griefs,
May have some scope to beat, or else I swoon
May happily bring forth. But who comes here?
May hang upon your hardness: therefore hear us.
May give you thankful sacrifice.
May fright the hopeful mother at the view;
May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take
May drop upon his kingdom and devour
May do much danger. Friar John, go hence;
May deem that you are worthily deposed.
May call it back again. Well, believe this,
May be put from her by society:
May be possessed with some store of crowns;
May be a precedent and witness good
May I change these garments?
Matters of needful value. We shall write to you,
Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me,
Mates, maid! how mean you that? no mates for you,
Match not the high perfection of my loss:
Masters, lay down your weapons.
Masters of the people,
Masters o' the people,
Masterly done:
Master:
Master:
Master, your love must live a maid at home;
Master, you look'd so longly on the maid,
Master, there is three carters, three shepherds,
Master, some show to welcome us to town.
Master, master, look about you: who goes there, ha?
Master, master! news, old news, and such news as
Master, it is no time to chide you now;

Master, has my fellow Tranio stolen your clothes? Or
Master, for my hand,
Master, a mercatante, or a pedant,
Master of this design, did give us, with

Marcius, 'tis true that you have lately told us;

Marcius!
Marcius would have all from you; Marcius,
Marcius coming home!
March'd toward Saint Alban's to intercept the queen,
March'd through the city to the palace gates.
March to assault thy country than to tread--
March sadly after; grace my mournings here;
March on, my fellows:
March on, march on, since we are up in arms;
March on, and mark King Richard how he looks.
Many years of happy days befal
Many that are not mad
Many good morrows to my noble lord!
Many for many virtues excellent,
Many and hearty thankings to you both.
Many a time hath banish'd Norfolk fought
Many a morning hath he there been seen,
Many a battle have I won in France,
Mann'd with three hundred men, as I have heard;
Manifest treason!
Mangles true judgment and bereaves the state
Man-enter'd thus, he waxed like a sea,
Maliciously like poison: but I cannot
Making them women of good carriage:
Making the mother, wife and child to see
Making the hard way sweet and delectable.
Making practise on the times,
Making not reservation of yourselves,
Making both it unable for itself,
Making another head to fight again.
Makes you think so.
Makes the survivor heir of all.
Makes the night morning, and the noon-tide night.
Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.
Makes me with heavy nothing faint and shrink.
Makes me most forward in this noble presence
Makes him to send; that thereby he may gather
Makes him speak fondly, like a frantic man
Makes fear'd and talk'd of more than seen--your son
Make yourselves scabs?
Make your best haste, and go not
Make way, unruly woman!
Make war with him that climb'd unto their nest,
Make war upon themselves; blood against blood,
Make us thy ministers of chastisement,
Make us pay down for our offence by weight
Make them be strong and ready for this hint,
Make thee the father of their idle dreams
Make the sun dance. Hark you!
Make the prize light.
Make that thy question, and go rot!
Make rash remonstrance of my hidden power
Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.
Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood
Make our eyes flow with joy, hearts dance
Make not too rash a trial of him, for
Make much of him, my lords, for this is he
Make motion through my lips, and my arm'd knees,
Make me, that nothing have, with nothing grieved,
Make me to think so twenty years together!
Make me not sighted like the basilisk:
Make it no wonder; if you knew my business,
Make haste; the hour of death is expiate.
Make haste; the bridegroom he is come already:
Make haste, make haste.
Make haste, I say.
Make good this ostentation, and you shall
Make feasts, invite friends, and proclaim the banns;
Make dust our paper and with rainy eyes
Make bold her bashful years with your experience;
Make a short shrift; he longs to see your head.
Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fires;
Maiden, no remedy.
Maid's mild behavior and sobriety.
Madest quick conveyance with her good aunt Anne.
Made up to the deed, doth push on this proceeding:
Made such a sinner of his memory,
Made prize and purchase of his lustful eye,
Made peace enmity, fair love of hate,
Made me exchange my state with Tranio,
Made me acquainted with a weighty cause
Made me a looker on here in Vienna,
Made issue from the bosom of the boy;
Made impudent with use of evil deeds,
Made him my book wherein my soul recorded
Made him joint-servant with me; gave him way
Made him a man; and though thou livest and breathest,
Made glory base and sovereignty a slave,
Made glorious summer by this sun of York;
Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub,
Made by some other deity than nature,
Made all of false-faced soothing!
Made a divorce betwixt his queen and him,

Love give me strength! and strength shall help afford.

Lord Angelo hath to the public ear

Look that you take upon you as you should;

Look forward on the journey you shall go.
